article_title: AM Roundup: Supreme Court Leaning Liberal Without Scalia
article_text:
Law Blog rounds up the morning’s legal news:

GRE v. LSAT: Arizona Law School’s decision to make the LSAT optional has put it on a collision course with the powerful national nonprofit group that administers the exam and controls much of the law-school application process nationwide. [WSJ]

SCOTUS leaning liberal: When the Supreme Court completed its last term last summer by upholding same-sex marriage and Obamacare, conservatives predicted a rebound this year. It hasn’t turned out that way. [USA Today]

• The number of cases justices have accepted has fallen. The high court has added only six to the docket since Justice Scalia’s death in February. [WaPo]

Police shooting convictions on the rise: A guilty verdict for a volunteer sheriff’s deputy in Oklahoma is the latest conviction of police in on-duty shootings, a departure from past years when officers were rarely even charged. Videos play a role, a prosecutor says. [WSJ]

Europe’s terror fight puts focus on U.S. laws: European counterterrorism officials say American laws and corporate policies are hampering their efforts to prevent the next attack. [WSJ]

Voter ID laws: More than a dozen states will use stricter voter identification laws laws for the first time in a presidential election this fall. [NYT]

Redstone’s mental competence: The legal battle over media mogul Sumner Redstone’s mental competence, which finally heads to court this week after transfixing Hollywood and Wall Street for months, features a cast of characters befitting a reality TV show. [WSJ]

Plaintiffs demand more cheese: Nearly 45 lawsuits have been filed alleging that leading brands of grated parmesan cheese fail to tell consumers that they contain additives such as cellulose. [NLJ]

• A lawsuit has been filed on behalf of consumers in New York and California against the owner of Quaker Oats after testing found traces of a pesticide in some oatmeal. [NYT]

NYC challenges ‘frivolous’ suits: New York City is cracking down on “frivolous” lawsuits against the NYPD amid soaring payouts to litigants and their lawyers. [NYP]

LGBT rights supporters protest Mississippi law: Hundreds of supporters of lesbian, gay bisexual and transgender rights protested Sunday against a new Mississippi law they call discriminatory. [AP]

Sheldon Silver sentencing: A federal judge is expected to decide Tuesday whether former New York Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver deserves a long prison sentence for years of corruption, or leniency because he’s ill and says he’s sorry. [WSJ]

Bergdahl case: An appeals court has cleared the way for U.S. Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s legal case to resume. [AP]
